snippet.textDisplay: Kant wasn't the first person to speculate about what could be called other galaxies or in the parlance of their times other universes.  You get it in thinkers in the middle ages who want a safe way to assert God's omnipotence being subject to Aristotelian physics.  Aristotle asserted there could be only one universe because there could only be one "center of gravity" or natural place for each substance. This seemed to some scholastic that was an easy way to assert divine omnipotence without a complete overhaul of the Aristotelian system.  Nicholas of Cusa even speculated about aliens.  Kant may have been the first one to talk about it within a Copernican worldview, but he wasn't the first one to talk about.
snippet.textOriginal: Kant wasn't the first person to speculate about what could be called other galaxies or in the parlance of their times other universes.  You get it in thinkers in the middle ages who want a safe way to assert God's omnipotence being subject to Aristotelian physics.  Aristotle asserted there could be only one universe because there could only be one "center of gravity" or natural place for each substance. This seemed to some scholastic that was an easy way to assert divine omnipotence without a complete overhaul of the Aristotelian system.  Nicholas of Cusa even speculated about aliens.  Kant may have been the first one to talk about it within a Copernican worldview, but he wasn't the first one to talk about.

snippet.textDisplay: Fascinating that scientific method is cast aside in favour of uniformitarianism. There is clear evidence of a lack of uniformity - in everything from radiometric decay, to erosion and plate techtonics. We have zero idea how old the earth is. Estimates, based on limited evidence - sure. But no definitive age, we could be billions of years out.
snippet.textOriginal: Fascinating that scientific method is cast aside in favour of uniformitarianism. There is clear evidence of a lack of uniformity - in everything from radiometric decay, to erosion and plate techtonics. We have zero idea how old the earth is. Estimates, based on limited evidence - sure. But no definitive age, we could be billions of years out.

snippet.textDisplay:
They say the age of the Observable Universe is around 14 billion years old. I think that saying that is a bit misleading, as it insinuates that nothing existed before then. But we openly agree that something existed prior to the moments before starting the stopwatch. Building a ship out of a Forrest doesn't mean the lumber used no longer exists but it doesn't add on to the age of the ship either. With that in mind, the Observable Universe doesn't add on the age of the stuff that went into it.

HOWEVER, if we are just talking about primitive cubic areas of volume, or what I like to call "The Open Field" where mother nature does all of her sandboxing, then we are talking agelessness. If energy can neither be created not destroyed, then the Open itself is saturated with potential energy. Is Open Field the right phrase? I feel like The Continuum Field or the Field of Continuum is a better official name of ... Whatever area it is Space-time is considered to be expanding in.
snippet.textOriginal:
They say the age of the Observable Universe is around 14 billion years old. I think that saying that is a bit misleading, as it insinuates that nothing existed before then. But we openly agree that something existed prior to the moments before starting the stopwatch. Building a ship out of a Forrest doesn't mean the lumber used no longer exists but it doesn't add on to the age of the ship either. With that in mind, the Observable Universe doesn't add on the age of the stuff that went into it.

HOWEVER, if we are just talking about primitive cubic areas of volume, or what I like to call "The Open Field" where mother nature does all of her sandboxing, then we are talking agelessness. If energy can neither be created not destroyed, then the Open itself is saturated with potential energy. Is Open Field the right phrase? I feel like The Continuum Field or the Field of Continuum is a better official name of ... Whatever area it is Space-time is considered to be expanding in.

snippet.textDisplay:
The early Christians were Jews. It was at the Council of Jerusalem, 50CE that "Christians" decided that it would no longer be necessary to circumcise converts. St. Paul, the effective founding CEO of Christianity, wrote in the New Testament that the Book of Genesis' story of Abraham's sons is "allegory/ figuratively" [Galatians 4:24]. In the 5th century CE Saint Augustine wrote that he "could scarcely keep from laughing" when hearing "idiotic" creationists claiming the the Book of Genesis is a literal account of creation:

1,500 years ago he wrote this about creationists:

"It not infrequently happens that something about the earth, about the sky, about other elements of this world, about the motion and rotation or even the magnitude and distances of the stars, about definite eclipses of the sun and moon, about the passage of years and seasons, about the nature of animals, of fruits, of stones, and of other such things, may be known with the greatest certainty by reasoning or by experience, even by one who is not a Christian. It is too disgraceful and ruinous, though, and greatly to be avoided, that he [the non-Christian] should hear a Christian speaking so idiotically on these matters, and as if in accord with Christian writings, that he might say that he could scarcely keep from laughing when he saw how totally in error they are. In view of this and in keeping it in mind constantly while dealing with the book of Genesis, I have, insofar as I was able, explained in detail and set forth for consideration the meanings of obscure passages, taking care not to affirm rashly some one meaning to the prejudice of another and perhaps better explanation.

With the scriptures it is a matter of treating about the faith. For that reason, as I have noted repeatedly, if anyone, not understanding the mode of divine eloquence, should find something about these matters [about the physical universe] in our books, or hear of the same from those books, of such a kind that it seems to be at variance with the perceptions of his own rational faculties, let him believe that these other things are in no way necessary to the admonitions or accounts or predictions of the scriptures. In short, it must be said that our authors knew the truth about the nature of the skies, but it was not the intention of the Spirit of God, who spoke through them, to teach men anything that would not be of use to them for their salvation."
snippet.textOriginal:
The early Christians were Jews. It was at the Council of Jerusalem, 50CE that "Christians" decided that it would no longer be necessary to circumcise converts. St. Paul, the effective founding CEO of Christianity, wrote in the New Testament that the Book of Genesis' story of Abraham's sons is "allegory/ figuratively" [Galatians 4:24]. In the 5th century CE Saint Augustine wrote that he "could scarcely keep from laughing" when hearing "idiotic" creationists claiming the the Book of Genesis is a literal account of creation:

1,500 years ago he wrote this about creationists:

"It not infrequently happens that something about the earth, about the sky, about other elements of this world, about the motion and rotation or even the magnitude and distances of the stars, about definite eclipses of the sun and moon, about the passage of years and seasons, about the nature of animals, of fruits, of stones, and of other such things, may be known with the greatest certainty by reasoning or by experience, even by one who is not a Christian. It is too disgraceful and ruinous, though, and greatly to be avoided, that he [the non-Christian] should hear a Christian speaking so idiotically on these matters, and as if in accord with Christian writings, that he might say that he could scarcely keep from laughing when he saw how totally in error they are. In view of this and in keeping it in mind constantly while dealing with the book of Genesis, I have, insofar as I was able, explained in detail and set forth for consideration the meanings of obscure passages, taking care not to affirm rashly some one meaning to the prejudice of another and perhaps better explanation.

With the scriptures it is a matter of treating about the faith. For that reason, as I have noted repeatedly, if anyone, not understanding the mode of divine eloquence, should find something about these matters [about the physical universe] in our books, or hear of the same from those books, of such a kind that it seems to be at variance with the perceptions of his own rational faculties, let him believe that these other things are in no way necessary to the admonitions or accounts or predictions of the scriptures. In short, it must be said that our authors knew the truth about the nature of the skies, but it was not the intention of the Spirit of God, who spoke through them, to teach men anything that would not be of use to them for their salvation."

snippet.textDisplay: This videos remind me of the ancient aliens series. A whole lot of speculation. The use of complex equations and jargon may convince some. Look into radiometric dating and you will see the inconsistencies and outright failures of this "scientific" technique.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have studied earth sciences myself, so this episode is a real breather for a change. No less fun or interesting, tough!

That being said, I feel that dismissing Ussher's attempt at calculating the age of the Earth as unscientific is not fair.
Ussher's methodology was more appropriate for a modern historian's job than a modern physicist's, but dismissing his work as unscientific as a result is rather... dismissive of humanities faculties at universities the world over.

It's as if, sometime in the future, we manage to find a working Grand Unifying Theory of Everything and dismiss all but one of the current attempts at one as unscientific because they took a wrong approach.
snippet.textOriginal:
I have studied earth sciences myself, so this episode is a real breather for a change. No less fun or interesting, tough!

That being said, I feel that dismissing Ussher's attempt at calculating the age of the Earth as unscientific is not fair.
Ussher's methodology was more appropriate for a modern historian's job than a modern physicist's, but dismissing his work as unscientific as a result is rather...    dismissive of humanities faculties at universities the world over. 

It's as if, sometime in the future, we manage to find a working Grand Unifying Theory of Everything and dismiss all but one of the current attempts at one as unscientific because they took a wrong approach.

snippet.textDisplay:
The concept of deep time stretching into billions of years is not actually new.
Practically every ancient civilization/religion has it. Ancient Egyptians, Vedic India, ancient Chinese & thus japanese & Koreans, Olmec/Mayans & Incans, Australian aboriginals etc.
In fact it's pretty much only the Abrahamic faiths that have the story of creation as a "recent" thing that happened a few thousand years ago.

snippet.textDisplay:
Blck hole singularities, of any shape, are a mathematical fiction, describing a limit situation.
In physical reality, the black hole interior never reaches singularity, because of 2 things combined. Stronger-than-light gravity slows time down to a stop. While in the faster running time on the outside, the hole's Hawking evaporation happens, and comes and catches you up. It wipes out the hole before the interior can ever reach singularity.
snippet.textOriginal:
Blck hole singularities, of any shape, are a mathematical fiction, describing a limit situation.
In physical reality, the black hole interior never reaches singularity, because of 2 things combined. Stronger-than-light gravity slows time down to a stop. While in the faster running time on the outside, the hole's Hawking evaporation happens, and comes and catches you up. It wipes out the hole before the interior can ever reach singularity.

snippet.textDisplay: I have issues with a lot of this. As for the date being found by carbon dating, one must know the age of the material used for the carbon. No one knows the real age of Earth or any planet. Being a Geologist I can see the time it took to make coal, oil, natural gas etc. I can see the sedimentary deposits took a long time etc. If U  turns into C over time why is there no 1/2 ones? If a life came from lightning hitting an ocean, making a one cell life, and all life came from this one cell, then why did this cell get smart and make a bird, fish, cow etc, then changed to a tree, grass, weed etc? All things need a male and female, so the one cell had to make both the very same time. If it was 4.5 billion years ago why don't we have a fish turning into a tree etc. We see no such half's or parts thereof. There is more to it than what is told.
snippet.textOriginal: I have issues with a lot of this. As for the date being found by carbon dating, one must know the age of the material used for the carbon. Being a Geologist I can see the time it took to make coal, oil, natural gas etc. I can see the sedimentary deposits took a long time etc. If U  turns into C over time why is there no 1/2 ones? If a life came from lightning hitting an ocean, making a one cell life, and all life came from this one cell, then why did this cell get smart and make a bird, fish, cow etc, then changed to a tree, grass, weed etc? All things need a male and female, so the one cell had to make both the very same time. If it was 4.5 billion years ago why don't we have a fish turning into a tree etc. We see no such half's or parts thereof. There is more to it than what is told.

snippet.textDisplay: Great video. I've been really annoyed recently at ppl arguing that the earth is 6k years old, the young earth creationist hypothesis. They seem to misunderstand or purposely misrepresent our scientific understanding of our planet.

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you so much for not editing out the breaths at the ends of each sentence! We are actually able to listen to, and contemplate each sentence momentarily while he draws breath for the next one. Instead of being bombarded by a non-stop stream of baffling scientific bullshit, we are able to absorb and understand the technical narrative, as it gives us time to process the information provided.
I wish I had more than one upvote to give you.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
When I was a little boy I had an operation in hospital. In late fifties, anesthaesia wasn't that we'll those days, so I had a vision. First I saw an endless row of galaxies, and an endless row of planets, and planet like earths. I got further away, and I saw that the whole universe was trapped in an enormous giant cave. Then I woke up. The surgery was still going on, but that's another story.
There is zero science in my dream, but I had some understanding in things like parallel universes, the expansion because of a large mass surrounding our universe.
I had 2 more surgeries in my life, but no dreams came up. Fortunately though I didn't wake up in pain either. I emphasise there is no science to be found in a dream.
snippet.textOriginal:

Then I woke up. The surgery was still going on, but that's another story.
There is zero science in my dream, but I had some understanding in things like parallel universes, the expansion because of a large mass surrounding our universe. 
I had 2 more surgeries in my life, but no dreams came up. Fortunately though I didn't wake up in pain either. I emphasise there is no science to be found in a dream.

snippet.textDisplay:
PBS please compose some songs themed on astrophysics. The lyrics should be written by astrophysicists. Don't make them simple. Matt should speak the lyrics as speech, but with a clear voice. Don't use old audios. Record something new. Matt should speak and not sing. But with a clear voice. The sound engineer then will create the melodies on the voice. It sounds better if you speak clearly and the engineer fixes the pitch afterwards if you aren't a singer. If you aren't a singer you cannot create clean sounds at all pitches, thus is wiser to record the wrong notes as a clear speech, and then they fix you on scale. Please use 7-stringed guitars and not synths, or high cut the high frequencies in order we get the tindre / the quality of the electric guitar. Play horror music, not soft pop.

Compose horrorish music with these scales please!!! Mystic Arabian (has three scale-shifts/modes) do, re#, mi, sol, sol#, si do, do#, mi, fa, sol#, la do#, re, fa, fa# la, la# (semitonally/fret steps: 0, +1, +3, +1, +3, +1, +3) (si = ti, do = C) It is chordable. Play on-scale chords. mood: mysterious Evil Shaolin (it has two modes/variants) do, re, re#, fa, fa#, sol#, la, si do#, re, mi, fa, sol, sol#, la#, si (semitonally/fret steps: 0, +1, +2, +1, +2, +1, +2, +1, +2) It is chordable. Play on-scale chords. mood: horrorish (for true horror play chromatically, atonally and many 11 semitones = Major seventh and 13 semitone intervals = Minor ninth=Augmented octave = one octave plus a semitone) The lyrics should be lectures. Do not write kindergarten lyrics. The result should sound like mysterious rock. Try the nonclassical scales I gave you. We need astrophysics propaganda. Astrophysical rock & astrophysical metal. Use the Mystic Arabian scale. Always compose songs to promote astrophysics. Do it. People remember the important things we did after we die. It is important to promote astrophysics. Just do it, many times, with many mysterious scaled non-keyboarded 7-stringed astrophysical rock.

The Hindu time measurements doesn't just stop at the day of bramha ... There is the year of bramha and then the life of bramha and then there are a number of bramha(s) before the current one and there would be more in the faaaar future ......



Please correct it ... If you know about this more and you think I'm wrong ...🙏🙏🙏

snippet.textDisplay: Thanks for the white hole explanation. Still lots to learn about them. I did intuitively also assume that white holes are quite impossible in our 'modern' universe and thought that they would be the starting event - the big bang - of a new universe inside black holes.
snippet.textOriginal: Thanks for the white hole explanation. Still lots to learn about them. I did intuitively also assume that white holes are quite impossible in our 'modern' universe and thought that they would be the starting event - the big bang - of a new universe inside black holes.

snippet.textDisplay:
Why couldn't The end of time/space into the last black hole return to the beginning? This is the common thing ALL black holes have... the singularity.
Would this make the universe a singular expression?
